2:I[87352,["/_next/static/chunks/780ed9f12bd597e3.js","/_next/static/chunks/93fb432403aebbdd.js","/_next/static/chunks/6ed45c29e6db9297.js","/_next/static/chunks/ca6e69eece0158a1.js","/_next/static/chunks/c6ed05d45582b587.js","/_next/static/chunks/359436006d412aab.js"],""]

26:I[19497,["/_next/static/chunks/f7a6a5c10098787e.js","/_next/static/chunks/0228e4c449c3a8b8.js"],"OutletBoundary"]
27:"$Sreact.suspense"

a:["$","aside",null,{"className":"hidden lg:block","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm sticky top-24","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"p-6","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"font-semibold mb-4","children":"Table of Contents"}],["$","nav",null,{"className":"space-y-2","children":[["$","a","0",{"href":"#understanding-the-argentine-rental-market","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors text-foreground","children":"Understanding the Argentine Rental Market"}],["$","a","1",{"href":"#key-differences-from-other-countries","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"Key Differences from Other Countries"}],["$","a","2",{"href":"#types-of-rentals","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 Garantía Problem"}],["$","a","4",{"href":"#why-it-exists","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"Why It Exists"}],["$","a","5",{"href":"#options-for-expats","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"Options for Expats"}],["$","a","6",{"href":"#where-to-search","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors text-foreground","children":"Where to Search"}],["$","a","7",{"href":"#online-platforms","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"Online Platforms"}],["$","a","8",{"href":"#real-estate-agents-inmobiliarias","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"Real Estate Agents (Inmobiliarias)"}],["$","a","9",{"href":"#the-viewing-process","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors text-foreground","children":"The Viewing Process"}],["$","a","10",{"href":"#red-flags-to-avoid","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"Red Flags to Avoid"}],["$","a","11",{"href":"#questions-to-ask","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"Questions to Ask"}],["$","a","12",{"href":"#documents-to-request","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"Documents to Request"}],["$","a","13",{"href":"#lease-agreement-essentials","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors text-foreground","children":"Lease Agreement Essentials"}],["$","a","14",{"href":"#what-should-be-included","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"What Should Be Included"}],["$","a","15",{"href":"#standard-terms","className":"block text-sm hover:text-primary transition-colors pl-4 text-muted-foreground","children":"Standard b:["$","div",null,{"className":"container px-4 md:px-6 -mt-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"relative aspect-[2/1] md:aspect-[3/1] max-h-[500px] rounded-xl overflow-hidden","children":["$","$L20",null,{"src":"/images/blog/argentina-renting.webp","alt":"The Complete Guide to Renting an Apartment in Argentina","fill":true,"className":"object-cover","priority":true}]}]}]
21:T2ac5,<p><h1>The Complete Guide to Renting an Apartment in Argentina</h1></p><p>Finding a place to live is your first major challenge as an expat in Argentina. The rental system here is unique—and often confusing for foreigners. Here's everything you need to know.</p><p><h2 id="understanding-the-argentine-rental-market">Understanding the Argentine Rental Market</h2></p><p><h3 id="key-differences-from-other-countries">Key Differences from Other Countries</h3></p>
<p>1. <strong>Guarantee Required</strong>: Most landlords require a garantía (property guarantee)</p>
<p>2. <strong>Cash Preferred</strong>: USD cash often gets discounts</p>
<p>3. <strong>Long Leases</strong>: Standard is 2-3 years (though shorter terms are becoming available)</p>
<p>4. <strong>Inflation Adjustments</strong>: Rents increase every 6-12 months</p>
<p>5. <strong>Broker Fees</strong>: Tenant typically pays commission</p><p><h3 id="types-of-rentals">Types of Rentals</h3></p><p><h4 id="Traditional Lease (Contrato de Alquiler)">Traditional Lease (Contrato de Alquiler)</h4></p>
<p>- 2-3 year commitment</p>
<p>- Requires garantía</p>
<p>- Rent adjustments every 6 months</p>
<p>- Most legally protected</p>
<p>- Best for long-term stays</p><p><h4 id="Temporary/Furnished (Alquiler Temporario)">Temporary/Furnished (Alquiler Temporario)</h4></p>
<p>- 1-12 month terms</p>
<p>- No garantía needed</p>
<p>- Fully furnished</p>
<p>- Higher monthly cost</p>
<p>- More flexible</p><p><h4 id="Room Rentals">Room Rentals</h4></p>
<p>- Shared apartment</p>
<p>- Monthly payments</p>
<p>- Minimal requirements</p>
<p>- Great for first arrivals</p><p><h2 id="the-garanta-problem">The Garantía Problem</h2></p><p>The biggest hurdle for expats is the garantía—a property owner who guarantees your rent.</p><p><h3 id="why-it-exists">Why It Exists</h3></p>
<p>Argentine law makes it difficult to evict tenants. Landlords protect themselves by requiring someone with local property to vouch for you.</p><p><h3 id="options-for-expats">Options for Expats</h3></p><p><h4 id="1. Garantía de Alquiler (Insurance)">1. Garantía de Alquiler (Insurance)</h4></p>
<p>- Pay monthly premium (~5-10% of rent)</p>
<p>- Insurance company acts as guarantor</p>
<p>- Accepted by most modern landlords</p>
<p>- Companies: Caja de Seguros, Sura, others</p><p><h4 id="2. Depósito en Garantía">2. Depósito en Garantía</h4></p>
<p>- 3-6 months rent as deposit</p>
<p>- Held in escrow</p>
<p>- Returned at lease end</p>
<p>- Not all landlords accept</p><p><h4 id="3. Find a Local Guarantor">3. Find a Local Guarantor</h4></p>
<p>- Argentine friend or family member</p>
<p>- Must own property</p>
<p>- Significant responsibility for them</p>
<p>- Most difficult for new expats</p><p><h4 id="4. Negotiate Without Garantía">4. Negotiate Without Garantía</h4></p>
<p>- Offer higher deposit</p>
<p>- Show strong income proof</p>
<p>- Shorter lease term</p>
<p>- Pay more months upfront</p>
<p>- Possible with foreign landlords</p><p><h4 id="5. Temporary Rentals">5. Temporary Rentals</h4></p>
<p>- Skip garantía entirely</p>
<p>- Pay premium for flexibility</p>
<p>- Good for first 3-6 months</p><p><h2 id="where-to-search">Where to Search</h2></p><p><h3 id="online-platforms">Online Platforms</h3></p><p><h4 id="Zonaprop">Zonaprop</h4></p>
<p>- Largest rental site</p>
<p>- Filter by neighborhood, price</p>
<p>- Many listings</p>
<p>- Direct contact with agents</p><p><h4 id="MercadoLibre">MercadoLibre</h4></p>
<p>- Classifieds section</p>
<p>- Individual landlords</p>
<p>- Variable quality</p>
<p>- Good for deals</p><p><h4 id="Airbnb (Short-term)">Airbnb (Short-term)</h4></p>
<p>- First month while searching</p>
<p>- Negotiate long-term directly with host</p>
<p>- More expensive but easy</p><p><h4 id="Expat Groups">Expat Groups</h4></p>
<p>- Facebook groups</p>
<p>- Sublets from leaving expats</p>
<p>- No garantía often needed</p>
<p>- Word-of-mouth deals</p><p><h3 id="real-estate-agents-inmobiliarias">Real Estate Agents (Inmobiliarias)</h3></p>
<p>- Professional service</p>
<p>- Access to better listings</p>
<p>- Help with paperwork</p>
<p>- Charge commission (usually 1 month rent)</p><p><h2 id="the-viewing-process">The Viewing Process</h2></p><p><h3 id="red-flags-to-avoid">Red Flags to Avoid</h3></p>
<p>- No written contract</p>
<p>- Cash only, no receipt</p>
<p>- Unwilling to show ownership papers</p>
<p>- Price too good to be true</p>
<p>- Rush to decide</p><p><h3 id="questions-to-ask">Questions to Ask</h3></p>
<p>- What's included? (utilities, expenses)</p>
<p>- How old is the building?</p>
<p>- What's the neighborhood like at night?</p>
<p>- Any planned construction nearby?</p>
<p>- Internet providers available?</p>
<p>- Pet policy?</p><p><h3 id="documents-to-request">Documents to Request</h3></p>
<p>- <strong>Titulo de Propiedad</strong>: Proof of ownership</p>
<p>- <strong>Expensas</strong>: Monthly building fees</p>
<p>- <strong>ABL</strong>: Property tax receipt</p>
<p>- <strong>Service bills</strong>: Recent utility amounts</p><p><h2 id="lease-agreement-essentials">Lease Agreement Essentials</h2></p><p><h3 id="what-should-be-included">What Should Be Included</h3></p>
<p>- Exact address and description</p>
<p>- Lease term and start date</p>
<p>- Monthly rent amount</p>
<p>- Payment method and due date</p>
<p>- Expenses (building fees) responsibility</p>
<p>- Maintenance responsibilities</p>
<p>- Early termination clauses</p>
<p>- Rent adjustment formula</p><p><h3 id="standard-terms">Standard Terms</h3></p>
<p>- <strong>Duration</strong>: Usually 2-3 years</p>
<p>- <strong>Rent Increases</strong>: Every 6-12 months (indexed to inflation)</p>
<p>- <strong>Deposit</strong>: 1-2 months rent</p>
<p>- <strong>Notice Period</strong>: Usually 2-3 months to terminate</p><p><h3 id="get-everything-in-writing">Get Everything in Writing</h3></p>
<p>Verbal promises mean nothing. If it's not in the contract, it doesn't exist.</p><p><h2 id="costs-beyond-rent">Costs Beyond Rent</h2></p><p><h3 id="upfront-costs">Upfront Costs</h3></p>
<p><tr><td>Item</td><td>Typical Cost</td></tr></p>
<p></p>
<p><tr><td>First month rent</td><td>1x monthly</td></tr></p>
<p><tr><td>Deposit</td><td>1-2x monthly</td></tr></p>
<p><tr><td>Broker commission</td><td>1x monthly</td></tr></p>
<p><tr><td>Garantía insurance (if used)</td><td>Setup fee + monthly</td></tr></p>
<p><tr><td>Moving costs</td><td>$100-500</td></tr></p><p><h3 id="monthly-expenses">Monthly Expenses</h3></p>
<p><tr><td>Expense</td><td>Typical Range</td></tr></p>
<p></p>
<p><tr><td>Building fees (expensas)</td><td>$50-200</td></tr></p>
<p><tr><td>Gas</td><td>$10-50</td></tr></p>
<p><tr><td>Electricity</td><td>$20-80</td></tr></p>
<p><tr><td>Water</td><td>$10-30</td></tr></p>
<p><tr><td>Internet</td><td>$20-40</td></tr></p>
<p><tr><td><strong>Total extras</strong></td><td><strong>$110-400</strong></td></tr></p><p><h2 id="negotiation-tips">Negotiation Tips</h2></p><p>1. <strong>Pay in USD Cash</strong>: Can get 10-20% discount</p>
<p>2. <strong>Longer Lease</strong>: Commit to 2+ years for better rate</p>
<p>3. <strong>Multiple Months Upfront</strong>: Offer 3-6 months for lower monthly</p>
<p>4. <strong>No Garantía</strong>: Accept higher deposit instead</p>
<p>5. <strong>Furnished vs Unfurnished</strong>: Unfurnished is cheaper but requires investment</p><p><h2 id="moving-in-checklist">Moving In Checklist</h2></p><p><h3 id="before-signing">Before Signing</h3></p>
<p>- [ ] Verify owner identity and ownership</p>
<p>- [ ] Inspect every room for damage</p>
<p>- [ ] Test all appliances</p>
<p>- [ ] Check water pressure and hot water</p>
<p>- [ ] Verify internet ports work</p>
<p>- [ ] Take dated photos of everything</p>
<p>- [ ] Get spare keys</p><p><h3 id="after-moving-in">After Moving In</h3></p>
<p>- [ ] Transfer utilities to your name</p>
<p>- [ ] Set up internet</p>
<p>- [ ] Get property tax (ABL) in your name</p>
<p>- [ ] Introduce yourself to building manager (encargado)</p>
<p>- [ ] Learn building rules and garbage schedule</p>
<p>- [ ] Get building access (fob/key)</p><p><h2 id="common-scams-to-avoid">Common Scams to Avoid</h2></p><p><h3 id="the-fake-landlord">The Fake Landlord</h3></p>
<p><strong>Scam</strong>: Rents apartment they don't own</p>
<p><strong>Prevention</strong>: Always request titulo de propiedad, verify ID matches</p><p><h3 id="the-bait-and-switch">The Bait and Switch</h3></p>
<p><strong>Scam</strong>: Shows great apartment, "rents" different one</p>
<p><strong>Prevention</strong>: Visit exact unit, get address in writing</p><p><h3 id="the-no-contract-deal">The No-Contract Deal</h3></p>
<p><strong>Scam</strong>: Cash only, no paperwork, "cheaper"</p>
<p><strong>Prevention</strong>: Always get official contract and receipts</p><p><h3 id="the-disappearing-deposit">The Disappearing Deposit</h3></p>
<p><strong>Scam</strong>: Keeps deposit with fake damages</p>
<p><strong>Prevention</strong>: Detailed move-in inspection with photos</p><p><h2 id="special-considerations-for-expats">Special Considerations for Expats</h2></p><p><h3 id="short-term-1-6-months">Short-Term (1-6 months)</h3></p>
<p>- Use temporary rental agencies</p>
<p>- Airbnb with monthly discount</p>
<p>- Expat Facebook groups</p>
<p>- Expect to pay more for flexibility</p><p><h3 id="medium-term-6-18-months">Medium-Term (6-18 months)</h3></p>
<p>- Negotiate traditional lease without garantía</p>
<p>- Offer higher deposit</p>
<p>- Consider room rental</p>
<p>- Use garantía insurance</p><p><h3 id="long-term-2-years">Long-Term (2+ years)</h3></p>
<p>- Worth getting garantía insurance</p>
<p>- Traditional lease best value</p>
<p>- Build local credit history</p>
<p>- Consider buying if staying 5+ years</p><p><h2 id="your-rights-as-a-tenant">Your Rights as a Tenant</h2></p><p>Argentine law strongly protects tenants:</p>
<p>- <strong>Eviction</strong>: Very difficult, takes months/years</p>
<p>- <strong>Rent Increases</strong>: Capped by law (though often ignored)</p>
<p>- <strong>Repairs</strong>: Landlord responsible for major repairs</p>
<p>- <strong>Privacy</strong>: Notice required for entry</p>
<p>- <strong>Contract</strong>: Must be honored by both parties</p><p><h3 id="if-problems-arise">If Problems Arise</h3></p>
<p>1. Document everything in writing</p>
<p>2. Contact inmobiliaria if applicable</p>
<p>3. Consult a lawyer (abogado)</p>
<p>4. File complaint at Defensor del Pueblo</p>
<p>5. Consider tenant associations</p><p><h2 id="conclusion">Conclusion</h2></p><p>Renting in Argentina requires patience, paperwork, and persistence. The garantía system is the biggest hurdle, but options exist. Take your time finding the right place, get everything in writing, and don't rush into anything.</p><p>Start with temporary housing while you learn the system. Once you understand the market, you'll find a great place at a fair price. Buenos Aires has options for every budget—you just need to know where to look.</p><p>Welcome home.</p>
c:["$","div",null,{"className":"container px-4 md:px-6 py-12","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"grid lg:grid-cols-[1fr_300px] gap-8 lg:gap-12","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-none","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-lg max-w-none dark:prose-invert prose-headings:scroll-mt-24 prose-a:text-primary hover:prose-a:underline prose-img:rounded-xl","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$21"}}],"$L22","$L23"]}],"$L24"]}]}]
